channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Border Officials Are Said to Have Caused El Paso Closure by Firing Anti-Drone Laser
item.description: People familiar with the episode said the use of the technology was not coordinated with the Federal Aviation Administration. Officials targeted what they thought was a drug cartel drone, but turned out to be a party balloon, they said.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian, Eric Schmitt, Kate Kelly, Hamed Aleaziz and Luke Broadwater
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Aviation Administration’s decision Tuesday night to close El Paso’s airspace up to 18,000 feet blindsided officials in El Paso.

item.title: What We Know About the El Paso Airspace Shutdown
item.description: The Trump administration blamed the disruptive halt on a cartel drone incursion, but others have disputed that explanation.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor, Karoun Demirjian, Luke Broadwater, Edgar Sandoval and Laura Chung
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shutdown at the airport in El Paso was lifted in less than eight hours, but not before disrupting travelers and businesses.

item.title: Weapons Used to Fight Drones Don’t Mix Well With Civilian Airspace
item.description: In the race to build anti-drone weapons intended for use in a war zone, it is unclear how they may be used safely in crowded skies.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: Center for a New American Security
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: The airspace over El Paso was unexpectedly closed Tuesday night.

item.title: Lawmakers Question Bondi Over Justice Dept. Under Her Watch
item.description: Her appearance came as the Justice Department was under scrutiny over the Epstein files, its approach toward the shootings in Minneapolis and its move to prosecute six lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Casey Wasserman Will Stay as Head of 2028 Olympics Despite Epstein Ties, Organizers Say
item.description: Casey Wasserman exchanged flirtatious messages over 20 years ago with Ghislaine Maxwell, a longtime companion of Jeffrey Epstein. The 2028 board said its review found no other indiscretions related to Mr. Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez, Shawn Hubler and Laurel Rosenhall
item.category: Los Angeles Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Games 2028 (LA28)
item.media:credit: Andreas Rentz/Getty Images
item.media:description: Organizers for the 2028 Olympics in Los Angeles stood by their chairman, Casey Wasserman, after his name surfaced in a recent batch of Jeffrey Epstein files.

item.title: Epstein Files Include Grainy Videos From Inside His Florida Home
item.description: The clips from Jeffrey Epstein’s home office appear to show him with young women.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley and David Enrich
item.media:credit: US Department of Justice
item.media:description: A still from a grainy black-and-white video showed Jeffrey Epstein’s home office in Florida.

item.title: U.S. Attorney Chosen to Replace Trump Pick Is Quickly Fired by White House
item.description: Federal judges had appointed Donald Kinsella, a veteran litigator, as top prosecutor in the Northern District of New York after the Trump administration’s nominee was found to be serving unlawfully.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Sarcone III, pictured, had been appointed U.S. attorney for the Northern District of New York by President Trump. Donald Kinsella was chosen on Wednesday to replace him.

item.title: India’s Prime Minister Faces Blowback Over Trade Deal With Trump to Lower Tariffs
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi won a big reduction of sky-high tariffs, but critics say he undermined Indian sovereignty and undercut the nation’s farmers.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Altaf Hussain/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India secured a new trade deal with the United States that had few details.

item.title: House Votes to Cancel Trump’s Canada Tariffs
item.description: Six Republicans joined nearly all Democrats to end the national emergency President Donald Trump had declared to impose tariffs on imports from Canada.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks crossing the Ambassador Bridge connecting Windsor, Canada, with Detroit.

item.title: James Van Der Beek, ‘Dawson’s Creek’ Actor, Dies at 48 After Cancer Battle
item.description: He first appeared in a hit TV drama as a wide-eyed 15-year-old who then grew up over six seasons. He announced he had cancer in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates
item.media:credit: Robert Galbraith/Reuters
item.media:description: James Van Der Beek in 2002. His character in “Dawson’s Creek” knew, as he put it, the “unyielding, merciless torture” of unrequited love.

item.title: In His Second Act, James Van Der Beek Starred Online as a Proud Dad and Family Man
item.description: The actor, who died on Wednesday, was most famous for “Dawson’s Creek,” but as he got older, he let fans into his real life as a father of six.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam
item.media:credit: Alex Goodlett/Getty Images
item.media:description: James Van Der Beek, who died on Wednesday, with two of his six children at a charity event in 2023.

item.title: Olympic Figure Skaters Are on Thin Ice Over Music Copyright Rules
item.description: Several athletes have found themselves caught up in controversies over musical choices before and during one of the biggest competitions of their careers.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Canadian ice dancing pair Zachary Lagha and Marjorie Lajoie performing on Saturday in Milan.

item.title: Gallup Will No Longer Track Presidential Approval Ratings
item.description: The monthly poll has been used to measure presidential performance for almost nine decades.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Igielnik
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gallup’s decision comes as President Trump has escalated his threats against the press, and has sued several news media organizations, including at least one pollster, over the last several years.

item.title: Eyeing the Midterms, Kennedy Pivots Toward Food and Away From Vaccines
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who focused heavily on vaccine policy in 2025, will spend this year talking up healthy eating.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
item.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the boxer Mike Tyson and Brooke Rollins, the agriculture secretary, at an event on Wednesday promoting Mr. Kennedy’s healthy eating agenda.

item.title: House Passes Strict Voter ID Bill, Amplifying Trump’s Claims of Fraud
item.description: The measure had no path forward in the Senate, where Democrats are all but certain to block it and Republicans have said they will not try to skirt filibuster rules to ram it through.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Jim Vondruska for The New York Times
item.media:description: The strict voter identification measure would require proof of American citizenship to vote and allow the Department of Homeland Security to seize voter rolls in any state.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Now Invite Democrats to Governors’ Meeting
item.description: Even as he reversed course on excluding Democrats, the president repeatedly attacked a Republican governor who had planned to oversee the meeting.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump denied that he had ever sought to exclude Democrats from the meeting.

item.title: Why Nancy Guthrie’s Disappearance Is Breaking Through the Noise
item.description: A vulnerable victim, an unknown perpetrator and a recognizable celebrity are all factors in a case that has captivated the public.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley
item.media:credit: Brandon Bell/Getty Images
item.media:description: Elements of Nancy Guthrie’s kidnapping case have set it apart, including the universality, and relatability, of the victim: an elderly mother in peril.

item.title: Bangladesh Holds First Elections After 2024 Student Protests
item.description: At the vanguard of Gen Z movements, protesters in Bangladesh ousted the prime minister in 2024. They now face the hard reality of winning change through elections.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das, Saif Hasnat and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: The Bangladesh Elections Are on Thursday. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Bangladesh is holding national elections for the first time since 2024, when a student movement ousted the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, is preparing to hold elections on Thursday.

item.title: Bud Cort, Who Starred in 1971’s ‘Harold and Maude,’ Dies at 77
item.description: The role, one of his first, made him a household name and a film idol of the anti-establishment 1970s. But it also limited his growth as an actor.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: CBS, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Bud Cort as the teenager Harold Chasen who falls in love with a 79-year-old woman in Hal Ashby’s movie “Harold and Maude,” from 1971. Panned at first, it became a cult classic.

item.title: Man Accused of Murdering His Father Once Sought to Seize Stranger’s Baby
item.description: Henry McGowan of New York is on trial for murder in Ireland and has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity. Prosecutors outlined a previous psychotic break.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins

item.title: When It’s Finally Cold Enough to Race Ice Yachts
item.description: On the Navesink River, a long and frigid winter has allowed a 135-year-old rivalry to be renewed.
item.dc:creator: Corey Kilgannon and Mimi d’Autremont
item.category: North Shrewsbury Ice Boat and Yacht Club
item.media:credit: Mimi d’Autremont for The New York Times

item.title: Spain’s Approach to Migration Is Overrated and Harmful
item.description: It appears democratically unworkable and may be stoking populism.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Caldwell
item.media:credit: Emilio Morenatti/Associated Press

item.title: Donald Trump, Pagan King
item.description: The president is returning to an ancient world, before morality mattered and when human actions were governed only by power.
item.dc:creator: Leighton Woodhouse
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: LaMonte McLemore, Founding Singer With the 5th Dimension, Dies at 90
item.description: His group notched smooth hippie-era hits like “Up, Up and Away” and “The Age of Aquarius” in embracing a genre-blurring sound they called “champagne soul.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:credit: David Redfern/Redferns, via Getty Images
item.media:description: LaMonte McLemore, second from left, performing with the 5th Dimension on television in 1970. With him, from left, were Florence LaRue, Ron Townson, Billy Davis Jr. and Marilyn McCoo. From 1969 to 1972, the group notched 20 Top 40 singles.

item.title: Baby, 17 Days Old, Found Dead From Fire That Killed Her Mother
item.description: Two days after a fatal house fire in Queens, firefighters returned to the wreckage and found Emma Alcantara’s body. She and her mother, Miguelina, lived in an illegal basement apartment.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman and Olivia Bensimon
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.media:description: The mother and baby who died in a Queens fire lived in a basement that had not been certified for occupancy. Seven other residents and two firefighters were injured.

item.title: Nurses at 4 N.Y.C. Hospitals Vote to End Strike, but It Continues at One
item.description: At Montefiore and Mount Sinai hospitals, health care workers ratified a deal to end the walkout, but nurses remain on the picket line at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Nurses at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital will continue their strike even as health care workers elsewhere approved a contract.

item.title: This Comet Stopped Spinning. Then It Started Rotating Backward.
item.description: The unusual event, never seen before, might be a way small comets are “blown to bits” in the solar system.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O’Callaghan
